section.name: TOPICS: ITALIAN CULTURE: FOOD & CULTURE OF ITALY

values.comments:
This course explores the anthropology of food and the cultural aspects of gastronomy in Italian History; it will analyze the links between food, culture, and language. Specifically, this course investigates how food factors into textual genres such as narrative, poetry, cinema, visual arts, and advertising. 

Students described this course as “fun,” “interesting,” “enjoy[able],” and “easy.” Other students commented that it was a “great course.” Another student described it as “the perfect class to take as an elective.” Students reported learning a lot from this course; one student commented that this course led to “enlighten[ment] on [Italian] food” while another stated that this course allowed students to “learn a lot about food and its role in not only Italian culture, but also various cultures throughout the world.” 

Professor Finotti was described as rather disorganized, although students thought he was “nice” and “engaging.” Another student said that Finotti was a “great teacher” and said that he, along with the TAs, was very easy to contact for help. Many students also found that the TAs were very helpful and “amazing,” although grading policies were questioned, especially the consistency between TAs. 

Some students found that the course was difficult because the “requirements and… guidelines were not very clear,” while others explained that this was due to the disorganization of the course. The student assessment of this class’s difficulty varied from reviewer to reviewer. Some found the course to be “really tough” while others commented that it was “easy overall.” Specific critiques on the intensity of the course centered around the group work, which was often difficult because some students “did not seem to take the course very seriously” and required film editing skills that the course did not teach, and therefore students thought the final project was very work intensive but “offered little regard in terms of learning.” The vast difference in apparent difficulty may be attributed to the amount a student is willing to work; some students noted that the class had a “serious free-loader issue” while others said the class was “very easy.” One student commented that certain TAs were easier graders and therefore it can be expected that this class leads to fairly high grades. Assignments include readings, class attendance, preparation, participation, oral responses, and a final oral presentation. The course is taught in English, and many students commented that it is not only directed towards students interested in Italian studies.
